poem:
**Remembrance**  

Scarred hands and medals meet the November chill,  
a parade of memories beneath a solemn sky.  
King and commoner lay wreaths on stone,  
each petal a whisper for those who won't return.  
In the silence, a nation bows, breath held—  
echoes of valor and whispered prayers  
threaded through the fabric of time.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Second world war veterans applauded as king leads Remembrance Sunday tributes Veterans of the second world war were applauded as they arrived at the Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, before being joined by royals and senior politicians to honour those who have died in conflict. King Charles laid the first wreath in recognition of those killed in wars and conflicts dating back to the first world war. He was followed by his". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
